TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit SplineQuaternionKeyFrame extends System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrame

Docs.summary: Animates from the value of the previous key frame to its own using splined interpolation.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This class is used as part of a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrameCollection> in conjunction with a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimationUsingKeyFrames> to animate a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Quaternion> property value along a set of key frames.
A key frame defines a segment of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimationUsingKeyFrames> to which it belongs. Each key frame has a target <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrame.Value%2A> and a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrame.KeyTime%2A>. The <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrame.KeyTime%2A> specifies the time at which the key frame's <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrame.Value%2A> should be reached. A key frame animates from the target value of the previous key frame to its own target value. It starts when the previous key frame ends and ends when its own key time is reached.
Spline key frames like <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame> create a variable transition between values that is determined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame.KeySpline%2A> property. Splined interpolation can be used to achieve more realistic "real world" timing effects such as acceleration and deceleration.

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

Docs.param: A value from 0.0 through 1.0 that specifies the percentage of time that has elapsed for this key frame.
Docs.summary: Interpolates, in a splined fashion, between the previous key frame value and the value of the current key frame, using the supplied progress increment.
Docs.returns: The output value of this key frame given the specified base value and progress.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::Windows::Media::Animation::KeySpline ^ KeySpline { System::Windows::Media::Animation::KeySpline ^ get(); void set(System::Windows::Media::Animation::KeySpline ^ value); };
member this.KeySpline : System.Windows.Media.Animation.KeySpline with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the two control points that define animation progress for this key frame.
Docs.value: The two control points that specify the cubic Bezier curve that defines the progress of the key frame.

remarks.format: ## Remarks To understand how a works, it is helpful to understand cubic Bezier curves. A cubic Bezier curve is defined by a start point, an end point, and two control points. The two coordinates in the define those two control points. When describing key splines, the start point of the Bezier curve is always 0, and the end point is always 1, which is why you define only the two control points. The resulting curve specifies how an animation is interpolated during a time segment; that is, the curve represents the rate of change in the animation's target attribute over the time segment. To better see the relationship between animation progress and a Bezier curve, see [Key Spline Animation Sample](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=160011). ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|
